foto_1: Net carbon assimilation during the first growth phase drives the initial surge in metabolic energy available for tissue construction.
dm_1: Accumulated structural mass at the first observation point represents the materialized output of early-stage biological growth.
lai_1: Green leaf surface area per unit ground area at time step one determines the capacity for solar radiation interception.
temp_1: Ambient thermal conditions during the primary interval modulate enzyme kinetics and general plant development rates.
straaling_1: Photons from shortwave radiation during phase one drive metabolic energy cycles and facilitate the primary photochemical response.
lai_0: Initial vegetation architecture establishes the baseline structural state of the crop prior to the first measurement period.
meldug_1: Fungal pathogen colonization by powdery mildew during phase one competes for nutrients and physically obstructs light absorption.
foto_2: Carbon fixation occurring in the second interval responds to the interplay between expanding leaf area and environmental stressors.
dm_2: Biomass measured as dry weight at the second milestone integrates cumulative growth gains while accounting for respiratory losses.
lai_2: Canopy area expansion during the second period increases the potential for photochemical energy conversion.
temp_2: Temperature readings during the second window influence both plant development speed and fungal spore germination rates.
straaling_2: Incoming light intensity at the second time step serves as the primary limiting factor for overall photochemical efficiency.
meldug_2: Disease progression during phase two is conditioned by previous inoculum levels and current environmental suitability.
middel_1: Chemical control agents applied during the first stage aim to neutralize existing fungal colonies and protect the crop.
mikro_1: Internal canopy moisture and heat characteristics during the first period dictate the success of pathogen survival.
foto_3: Photosynthetic performance during the third phase reflects the physiological health of the crop after prolonged environmental exposure.
dm_3: Organic matter accumulation at the third interval provides a benchmark for total vegetative success before final maturation.
lai_3: Leaf coverage maintained into the third phase supports the necessary energy flow for grain or fruit development.
temp_3: Heat patterns recorded in the third time step determine the duration of the grain-filling or fruit-set period.
straaling_3: Cumulative radiant flux during the third window powers the late-season metabolic transition from growth to storage.
meldug_3: Infection severity at time step three accelerates senescence and significantly reduces the functional green area.
middel_2: Secondary fungicidal intervention modifies the epidemic trajectory by disrupting the lifecycle of the target pathogen.
mikro_2: Humidity and heat pockets within the foliage during phase two create localized microclimates that favor pest proliferation.
foto_4: Terminal carbon capture efficiency determines the ultimate nutrient density and size of the harvested product.
dm_4: Finalized dry mass measured at the end of the growth cycle quantifies the plant's aggregate productivity.
lai_4: Late-season vegetation coverage ensures that remaining nutrient stores are efficiently translocated to harvestable tissues.
temp_4: Thermal forcing during the final interval triggers physiological ripening and moisture reduction in the crop.
straaling_4: Solar energy received during the terminal phase supports final metabolic processes required for maturity.
meldug_4: End-of-season fungal pressure impacts the aesthetic and nutritional quality of the final harvest.
middel_3: Late-stage application of crop protection products serves to safeguard the harvest against opportunistic late-season pathogens.
mikro_3: Site-specific micro-environmental variables at time step three modulate the persistence of chemical residues and pathogen viability.
nedboer_1: Precipitation events during the first period regulate soil water availability and influence the humidity necessary for spore dispersal.
nedboer_2: Rainfall accumulation during the second phase affects nutrient transport within the soil and alters the canopy moisture profile.
nedboer_3: Moisture supplied by rain during the third interval manages heat stress through evaporative cooling and maintains cellular turgor.
udbytte: Economic yield at harvest integrates every preceding causal interaction between management, environment, and plant biology.
